stories.text:
I'm suffering from a bit of a burnout from BigCo work and want to rediscover the feeling of figuring out a new framework or a programming language and building something fun with it.

Most of the tools I work with on my job are exceptionally slow and are highly specific internal frameworks and I would really like a change of pace from that. I've also been blind to things happening in the outside world for the past 5-6 years, so I probably missed a decent chunk of how modern web / service development is done.

I don't want to constrain the problem space, anything from systems programming to data science is on the table, so throw me something interesting!
stories.title: Ask HN: BigCo Burnout, Hacking over the Holidays

stories.text:
Inspired by this thread: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=29581125

So I want to spend my time researching and translating esoteric Tibetan texts. There’s zero money in that.

What I need is basically what the person in the above thread does - 10 hours a week would be amazing, but I don’t want to feel like I’m scamming my employer to get it. Keeping up some pretence of work doesn’t seem like a good idea ethically or for my own mental health.

I don’t need a big salary, I can quite easily live on 30-40k.

I’m at the beginning of my career as a developer. Reading the linked thread I kind of despair at the fact that hardly anyone seems willing to give part time contracts when it seems a lot of developers don’t work full time anyway. Are there ways to do this legitimately as a developer, or do you basically have to be in a big company where you can coast?
stories.title: Ask HN: How to work minimally, legitimately (inspired by developers lying post)
